. For the chmod and xattrs being cleaned up, it's because dropbox uses a default umask of 0644 for files, and when you sync your ssh keys (or any other license) you don't (and can't for ssh) have your key files readable by anyone.
As I don't think it make sense for any user config file to be readable by anyone, I just blindly enforce a mode of 0600 to any synced file.
The xattrs are cleaned up, because OS X use them to set some ACL that prevent mackup to move some files around too, and I don't see the point of keeping those special ACLs if I 0600 any file. But I might be wrong here.
About hostusernamemap, if you think it's a file that should be synced, we can add it to the list, feel free to tell me which file to sync here as I'm not a user of SourceTree.

It's true that merging apps and features in a single commit does not make it easy to review/merge.
But also some features require more thoughts before getting merged in.
Mackup is touching user's files and we don't want to mess anyone's system out there.
Regarding the other fork, I've been told that the guy spammed mackup's contributors. He got excited, forked and changed the name, merged some PR and that's about it. I don't really care but let me help you with the link ;) https://github.com/matyhaty/dropboxAppSync
On mackup side, the big plan is to lay down a clear path for the features that have been asked. I don't care about the implementation, but the UX is important: it's a complex problem and I'm very careful to not make Mackup too complex (e.g. with command line args and config files in multiple formats that conflict each other).
Hope that clarifies =)

Re what to do: Frankly I don't know, I never got the time to deeply think about it, and I don't want you to do something that's not gonna be used.
But in order to advance, I can tell you what I'm sure of: You can close this PR and create new ones:
- One per app for each app supported (or with improved support if it's already in, I remember having merged some from you)
- One for the custom apps feature. Whatever happens, this feature will be built and I'll merge your PR, or worst case, use your PR as a starting point.
Regarding the feature, here are some thoughts:
- It can be a big json file containing all the apps, near the binary, or a bunch of small json files, one per app, in a dedicated folder.
- The actual json format used in mackup is simple (a list of path for each path) but it prevents us to do more, e.g. specify permissions for certain files, or specify files to exclude. It needs to be more specific and support future changes.
- Do we put the json in the same repo (like homebrew) or in a different repo, acting as a mac application database that can be worked on separately.
- What about ini or yaml as a file format ?
- The installer needs to be improved if mackup is not just one file anymore, homebrew is fine.
There we go. If you create a new PR, feel free to paste/rephrase those questions, IMHO those need to be answered before starting the implementation.
Thanks for digging this up ;)

. Do you mean linking files directly works ?
(e.g. instead of linking Containers/Sip you link Containers/Sip/File1 and Containers/Sip/File2)
. Yeah, links are ruled out. The app dev need to ask for permissions when submitting to the app store and tell which file outside of the Container app folder it needs to access, with a good reason.
Hard links or file copy are the only options here.
But hard links are not supported by dropbox (it wont detect changes)
And file copy means mackup need to watch over those files for changes from time to time.
Mackup could add itself to the user's crontab and diff/sync those files every X min, keeping latest modified all the time (local or dropbox), but there might be problems when multiple computers are on.
. We don't need 2 "taps" to handle apps differently, a simple config option in the app cfg can work.
e.g.
[application]
name = Super Duper
sync_method = copy
For this app mackup will not link the conf files, but just copy them when it's being run.
Then as you mentioned, the real problem here is that we let users in the dark, not knowing what's in sync.
That's where the mackup status feature in the TODO can help.
It could display the list of apps both installed locally or not installed but with a conf in Dropbox.
For each of them it would say in sync or show when the last sync have been done, or even if it has never been done.
Obviously, for apps with linked config files, it would always display in sync, but at least the user could know what config is outdated (from the apps with a copy sync_method) and showing that it has not been synced for 20 days can help the user decide.
Making mackup optin instead of optout is another question.
. Cool I guess we have a plan then, thanks for helping clarifying this out.

1. split out mackup from one big main.py to a bunch of modules (that was the point of 0.6 work)
2. implement a status option
3. implement a copy sync method
4. add app store apps in

There should be a way to flush the cache of cfprefsd. Anyway, it seems that we should not modify plist files directly anymore, and use "official" ways instead:
- defaults read|write
- python CoreFoundation
We could import/export specific things with those, the problem is that it won't sync anymore after the initial sync. And even if we dump the output in a file, we would have to do it constantly, which is not an option, as it's dropbox who's monitoring file content, and I can't make dropbox call mackup.
So we are hitting a wall here. Either there is a way to disable this cfprefsd caching behavior, either we use an interface to sync the plists and do it all the time.
The last solution is to not support those apps and wait and see.
In the short term, should we remove support for those and blacklist those until we have a plan ?
. defaults write/read can only happen when you launch mackup to sync/restore, there is no way we can monitor the defaults to sync them in dropbox.

How one might migrate the backup folder from dropbox to say, copy or googledrive?

I never tried it, but you should be able to do this following those steps:
1. Make sure everything is in sync and up to date:
   1. Upgrade Mackup
   2. Do a mackup backup
   3. Do a mackup restore
2. Do a mackup uninstall to bring back your setting files into your home folder.
3. Configure Mackup to use Google Drive (see https://github.com/lra/mackup/tree/master/doc#google-drive)
4. Do a mackup backup to move you setting files into Google Drive
If you have another workstation using mackup, do all the steps, but replace the last step (mackup backup) by a mackup restore
Let me know if it works, and I'll add this to the doc.
You can also do a pull request to update the doc if you want ;)

. For the ones who come here, if upgrading mackup breaks your config, because the list of synced files for your app changes, the safest way to upgrade is to:
On your main workstation:
1. mackup uninstall
2. Upgrade mackup
3. mackup backup
And on your other workstations:
1. mackup uninstall
2. Upgrade mackup
3. mackup restore
A bit of a pain, but until we come up with a solid plan, I don't see a better way =(
. Shower thinking... (I think a lot in the shower ;)
Here some thoughts to advance on this:
An application config right now looks like:
``` ini
[application]
name = Arara
[configuration_files]
.araraconfig.yaml
araraconfig.yaml
```
What about a new obsolete_configuration_files section where we would move the configuration files that were previously synced by mackup, but superseeded in a previous version by the ones listed under configuration_files ?
For example, it would look like:
``` ini
[application]
name = Arara
[configuration_files]
.araraconfig.yaml
araraconfig.yaml
[obsolete_configuration_files]
.arara
```
Each time mackup would check the files of this application to see if it has anything to sync, upon finding one of the obsolete_configuration_files, it could just do a mackup uninstall only for this app, followed by a new mackup backup, only for this file again.
This works for the main workstation.
In case of a 2nd workstation, being synced after the 1st one, if an old obsolete_configuration_files link exists, it would just kill it, and do a mackup restore of this app.
Looks like it can work, but would like other eyes on this algo to make sure I'm not overlooking a possible state where it could fuck up some user's files.

``` python
!/usr/bin/env python
import sys
import os.path
try:
    import mackup.main
except ImportError:
    # If Mackup is not installed globally, we are looking for the mackup module
    # at the same path level as the bin folder where this script is in.
    # In this case, let's dynamically add the parent path to the python path
    bin_dir_path = os.path.dirname(os.path.realpath(file))
    parent_dir_path = os.path.dirname(bin_dir_path)
    sys.path.append(parent_dir_path)
    try:
        import mackup.main
    except ImportError:
        # We are being run on a half-backed system (cough brew bot cough)
        # Let's hack our way in
        hacky_packages_path = os.path.join(parent_dir_path,
                                           'lib/python2.7/site-packages')
        # On some systems mackup is running 2.6 python
        # See https://github.com/lra/mackup/issues/263
        if not os.path.isdir(hacky_packages_path):
            hacky_packages_path = os.path.join(parent_dir_path,
                                               'lib/python2.6/site-packages')
        sys.path.append(hacky_packages_path)
        import mackup.main
if name == 'main':
    mackup.main.main()
```

. At some point, I'd like Mackup to be transactional. Instead of changing files directly, it would make a copy of the files in some isolated area (the temp folder), try doing the work there, and if all is ok, apply the same on the real files. If any failure in the middle of the work, it would just erase the temp folder, and the original files would not be touched.
I also wanted to know if creating/deleting this temp folder would generate problems on some user's weird config, apparently nobody complains, and keeping this code make sure we can do the transactional feature without worrying about the "where do we put the files?" part.
Only the temp folder creation/deletion has been implemented yet ;)

[application]

. I certainly prefer this version:
```
[application]
name = Git
[configuration_files]
$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/git/config
$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/git/credentials
$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/git/ignore
.gitignore
.gitcredentials
.gitconfig
```
The version with the || is just overkill and a pain to parse and handle.
I guess we could evaluate this $XDG_CONFIG_HOME but it breaks one of the rule of mackup: only relative path (to prevent stupid PRs trying to link things outside of home)
Maybe we could require that $XDG_CONFIG_HOME is a subfolder of home, but what if some dumb user set $XDG_CONFIG_HOME to /usr/share/I/dont/understand/unix. It's dumb but will surely happen.
. That's interesting. Going one step further, what about:
``` ini
[application]
name = Git
[home_config_paths]
.gitignore
.gitcredentials
.gitconfig
[xdg_config_paths]
git/config
git/credentials
git/ignore
```
home_config_paths would prefix $HOME and xdg_config_paths would prefix $XDG_CONFIG_HOME

[application]

We do chmod all the synced files because they are supposed to be configuration files, and some files have keys and credentials.
As we copy the files to 3rd party software (e.g. dropbox) and some of them apply stupid permissions to those files, we had to go the conservative route (0600 on files and 0700 on folders).
This is not fixable as it depends on the behavior of those cloud storage services, and they are not consistent.
Sorry, but the only way here is to not sync executable files, just config files. I suggest removing those files from the list of files to sync.

. For the chmod and xattrs being cleaned up, it's because dropbox uses a default umask of 0644 for files, and when you sync your ssh keys (or any other license) you don't (and can't for ssh) have your key files readable by anyone.
As I don't think it make sense for any user config file to be readable by anyone, I just blindly enforce a mode of 0600 to any synced file.
The xattrs are cleaned up, because OS X use them to set some ACL that prevent mackup to move some files around too, and I don't see the point of keeping those special ACLs if I 0600 any file. But I might be wrong here.
About hostusernamemap, if you think it's a file that should be synced, we can add it to the list, feel free to tell me which file to sync here as I'm not a user of SourceTree.

Re what to do: Frankly I don't know, I never got the time to deeply think about it, and I don't want you to do something that's not gonna be used.
But in order to advance, I can tell you what I'm sure of: You can close this PR and create new ones:
- One per app for each app supported (or with improved support if it's already in, I remember having merged some from you)
- One for the custom apps feature. Whatever happens, this feature will be built and I'll merge your PR, or worst case, use your PR as a starting point.
Regarding the feature, here are some thoughts:
- It can be a big json file containing all the apps, near the binary, or a bunch of small json files, one per app, in a dedicated folder.
- The actual json format used in mackup is simple (a list of path for each path) but it prevents us to do more, e.g. specify permissions for certain files, or specify files to exclude. It needs to be more specific and support future changes.
- Do we put the json in the same repo (like homebrew) or in a different repo, acting as a mac application database that can be worked on separately.
- What about ini or yaml as a file format ?
- The installer needs to be improved if mackup is not just one file anymore, homebrew is fine.
There we go. If you create a new PR, feel free to paste/rephrase those questions, IMHO those need to be answered before starting the implementation.

. Do you mean linking files directly works ?
(e.g. instead of linking Containers/Sip you link Containers/Sip/File1 and Containers/Sip/File2)
. Yeah, links are ruled out. The app dev need to ask for permissions when submitting to the app store and tell which file outside of the Container app folder it needs to access, with a good reason.
Hard links or file copy are the only options here.
But hard links are not supported by dropbox (it wont detect changes)
And file copy means mackup need to watch over those files for changes from time to time.
Mackup could add itself to the user's crontab and diff/sync those files every X min, keeping latest modified all the time (local or dropbox), but there might be problems when multiple computers are on.
. We don't need 2 "taps" to handle apps differently, a simple config option in the app cfg can work.
e.g.
[application]
name = Super Duper
sync_method = copy
For this app mackup will not link the conf files, but just copy them when it's being run.
Then as you mentioned, the real problem here is that we let users in the dark, not knowing what's in sync.
That's where the mackup status feature in the TODO can help.
It could display the list of apps both installed locally or not installed but with a conf in Dropbox.
For each of them it would say in sync or show when the last sync have been done, or even if it has never been done.
Obviously, for apps with linked config files, it would always display in sync, but at least the user could know what config is outdated (from the apps with a copy sync_method) and showing that it has not been synced for 20 days can help the user decide.
Making mackup optin instead of optout is another question.

. This is super lame, and we are not the only ones to be annoyed (http://rixstep.com/2/2/20130225,00.shtml)
There should be a way to flush the cache of cfprefsd. Anyway, it seems that we should not modify plist files directly anymore, and use "official" ways instead:
- defaults read|write
- python CoreFoundation
We could import/export specific things with those, the problem is that it won't sync anymore after the initial sync. And even if we dump the output in a file, we would have to do it constantly, which is not an option, as it's dropbox who's monitoring file content, and I can't make dropbox call mackup.
So we are hitting a wall here. Either there is a way to disable this cfprefsd caching behavior, either we use an interface to sync the plists and do it all the time.
The last solution is to not support those apps and wait and see.
In the short term, should we remove support for those and blacklist those until we have a plan ?
. defaults write/read can only happen when you launch mackup to sync/restore, there is no way we can monitor the defaults to sync them in dropbox.
Also it does not support structured data (like sublists)
It could be used in the future, but it would mean building a daemon or a cron-like caller.
. Frankly, until there is a workaround to this issue, I think we should just ditch support for those apps.
Like you said, when the user is not able to trust an application (mackup) it's the worst, and I want mackup to be as clear as it was in the beginning: syncing config files for apps, If an app cache some conf, too bad for the app.

I wanted a tool that does not require me to act each time I change some application setting. You say it's not happening a lot, but I can assure you that it happened a lot (Text editor setting, favorite song, bookmark, ...), this is exactly why I built this at 1st: I was bored of git pushing my changes and bored of having to do a change at home I had done at work that I forgot to push. It happened all the time =)
Also, without linking, if you forget to update one file, and you update the same file differently on another computer, you got a conflict.
The only case where it would work is if mackup was checking all its files from time to time. But thats why I used dropbox in the 1st place: It does it well already and I'd rather focus on solving mackup problems.
But that's something worth considering as the field of conf files gets harder in the future, because of app store containers for example.

How one might migrate the backup folder from dropbox to say, copy or googledrive?

I never tried it, but you should be able to do this following those steps:
1. Make sure everything is in sync and up to date:
   1. Upgrade Mackup
   2. Do a mackup backup
   3. Do a mackup restore
2. Do a mackup uninstall to bring back your setting files into your home folder.
3. Configure Mackup to use Google Drive (see https://github.com/lra/mackup/tree/master/doc#google-drive)
4. Do a mackup backup to move you setting files into Google Drive
If you have another workstation using mackup, do all the steps, but replace the last step (mackup backup) by a mackup restore
Let me know if it works, and I'll add this to the doc.
You can also do a pull request to update the doc if you want ;)

. For the ones who come here, if upgrading mackup breaks your config, because the list of synced files for your app changes, the safest way to upgrade is to:
On your main workstation:
1. mackup uninstall
2. Upgrade mackup
3. mackup backup
And on your other workstations:
1. mackup uninstall
2. Upgrade mackup
3. mackup restore
A bit of a pain, but until we come up with a solid plan, I don't see a better way =(

Here some thoughts to advance on this:
An application config right now looks like:
``` ini
[application]
name = Arara
[configuration_files]
.araraconfig.yaml
araraconfig.yaml
```
What about a new obsolete_configuration_files section where we would move the configuration files that were previously synced by mackup, but superseeded in a previous version by the ones listed under configuration_files ?
For example, it would look like:
``` ini
[application]
name = Arara
[configuration_files]
.araraconfig.yaml
araraconfig.yaml
[obsolete_configuration_files]
.arara
```
Each time mackup would check the files of this application to see if it has anything to sync, upon finding one of the obsolete_configuration_files, it could just do a mackup uninstall only for this app, followed by a new mackup backup, only for this file again.
This works for the main workstation.
In case of a 2nd workstation, being synced after the 1st one, if an old obsolete_configuration_files link exists, it would just kill it, and do a mackup restore of this app.
Looks like it can work, but would like other eyes on this algo to make sure I'm not overlooking a possible state where it could fuck up some user's files.

        # On some systems mackup is running 2.6 python

        if not os.path.isdir(hacky_packages_path):

if name == 'main':

. At some point, I'd like Mackup to be transactional. Instead of changing files directly, it would make a copy of the files in some isolated area (the temp folder), try doing the work there, and if all is ok, apply the same on the real files. If any failure in the middle of the work, it would just erase the temp folder, and the original files would not be touched.
I also wanted to know if creating/deleting this temp folder would generate problems on some user's weird config, apparently nobody complains, and keeping this code make sure we can do the transactional feature without worrying about the "where do we put the files?" part.
Only the temp folder creation/deletion has been implemented yet ;)

. I certainly prefer this version:
```
[application]
name = Git
[configuration_files]
$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/git/config
$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/git/credentials
$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/git/ignore
.gitignore
.gitcredentials
.gitconfig
```
The version with the || is just overkill and a pain to parse and handle.
I guess we could evaluate this $XDG_CONFIG_HOME but it breaks one of the rule of mackup: only relative path (to prevent stupid PRs trying to link things outside of home)
Maybe we could require that $XDG_CONFIG_HOME is a subfolder of home, but what if some dumb user set $XDG_CONFIG_HOME to /usr/share/I/dont/understand/unix. It's dumb but will surely happen.
. That's interesting. Going one step further, what about:
``` ini
[application]
name = Git
[home_config_paths]
.gitignore
.gitcredentials
.gitconfig
[xdg_config_paths]
git/config
git/credentials
git/ignore
```
home_config_paths would prefix $HOME and xdg_config_paths would prefix $XDG_CONFIG_HOME
. you are right, let's go one step further to keep it backward compatible:
``` ini
[application]
name = Git
[configuration_files]
.gitignore
.gitcredentials
.gitconfig
[xdg_configuration_files]
git/config
git/credentials
git/ignore
```

. https://github.com/lra/mackup/blob/master/mackup/utils.py#L112
We do chmod all the synced files because they are supposed to be configuration files, and some files have keys and credentials.
As we copy the files to 3rd party software (e.g. dropbox) and some of them apply stupid permissions to those files, we had to go the conservative route (0600 on files and 0700 on folders).
This is not fixable as it depends on the behavior of those cloud storage services, and they are not consistent.
Sorry, but the only way here is to not sync executable files, just config files. I suggest removing those files from the list of files to sync.

How does one copy prefs from outside the user folder ?

It is not supported, Mackup is all about user config, and there is no easy way to solve conflicts if it's start messing with other files on the system. (e.g. 2 users using Mackup)
Any sane application should save its config in the user folder anyway.

. Hey guys, thanks for all your replies so far.
I can see that many of us are concerned to perform this task, and sometimes we might not know exactly how things happen behind the scenes and how it could break your file system.
Don’t you think it would be better if we understood the limitations and how to work with keychain instead? 
Of course we must be cautious, but this is a feature that a lot of people would benefit from.
I have manually symlinked the keychain files as well and have been using it for a few months now. I got problems when first migrating the keychain over to dropbox, which was then sorted out, then a few surprises along the way, while I have two applications (Twitter and CloudApp), not storing passwords anymore as well as not remembering the last one I have used. So I have to type it every time I open the application. 
This only happened with these two softwares and am still trying to figure out why. 
iCloud keychain only stores Internet password and just shared amongst Safari instances on apple devices. Symlinking the login keychain sounded a good idea since I would lose all my passwords when migrating to a new computer or formatting the old one. 
After your considerations, I would have a few questions if you don’t mind:
- @jrnk: What happens when using 2 macs at the same time? Would it be possible to have them writing to the keychain file at the same time? Reading the keychain file at the same time brings any problem?
- @jannae How can keychain files get corrupted? Wouldn’t the risk be the same for these files becoming corrupted under your ~/Library/Keychains folder? — Where just the location differs
Thanks once again and have a great day.

ipmcc:
Or what about just rsyncing the files rather than symlinking?
. Well, by default, Dropbox Encore puts the host file in ~/.dropbox-two/.dropbox/host.db, but knowing that doesn't really help, because even if you can detect the presence of Dropbox Encore, there's no way to know (without input from the user) which Dropbox they want to use for Mackup. Furthermore, unlike the stock Dropbox client, Encore lets you put the second Dropbox dot-directory anywhere you want (~/.dropbox-two just happens to be the default.)
To me it seems like automatically detecting the standard case (one Dropbox account, used as installed by the standard Dropbox installer) is going to cover 99.99% of people who want to use Mackup. Adding an environment variable to override that for the other 0.01% seems like an apt solution. 
Alternately, I guess it could be an option in .mackup.cfg. The environment variable approach was the first thing that popped into my mind because that's the strategy homebrew seems to have taken, and I've been mucking about with it a bunch lately.

Yep, from my limited testing right now, (sip, where only one file needs to be linked, and sketch, where we need to link one file and a directory), it seems like linking directories inside containers is the only case where it causes problems (in sketch’s case you lose important settings, like the customisation of your toolbar).
. Seems to be the case, yes. Linking ~/Library/Cotainers/com.ruiaureliano.Sip/Data/Library/Preferences/com.ruiaureliano.Sip.plist works for sip, but linking ~/Library/Cotainers/com.bohemiancoding.sketch/Data/Library/Preferences/com.bohemiancoding.sketch.plist and ~/Library/Cotainers/com.bohemiancoding.sketch/Data/Library/Application Support/sketch does not work for sketch.
Linking individual files would not be a long-term solution, however, as in some cases whole directories do have to be copied over. In sketch, for instance, inside that linked directory is where user plugins reside, and those will be different depending on the user.
. New development. It seems that this can break or not on a case-by-case basis, so we should probably just get a solution that’ll act on files inside Containers, and settle on that, for those cases. Readkit, while only needing two files to maintain it’s settings, will break if the one inside Application Support is a symlink. Also, other apps (like Sip, mentioned previously), seem to no longer work with symlinks, after running new tests. I’m not sure what’s different, but we shouldn’t rely on something that might-or-not work, and find a more permanent solution.
. I agree that using cron (or launchd, even), is not an optimal solution, and should really be avoided.
The issue here seems to be how to convey to the user that some apps will have limited backup capabilities, so it is clear that those will need a bit more care to be kept up to date.
I don’t have a solution to this, but maybe the start of a suggestion. Since applications will essentially be divided into two groups (“always in sync” and “sync on demand”), maybe actually splitting them could help make that distinction (I’m thinking something to the effect of how homebrew uses taps). This way there would be an “opt-in” to these apps, making users aware of the why of this limitation.
Another option would be to only sync apps specified in the .mackup.cfg file, effectively forcing users to set it up, and be conscious about the limitations of certain cases (maybe apps would have to be organised under different sections of the file).
Both this options have the particularity of not making users worry about “is this app automatically synced, or do I have to do it myself regularly?”, since they’d be made aware of that when setting up, but they do come with the burden of requiring a bit extra work when initially setting up. I believe that initial hurdle to be more advantageous than having users puzzled about why some backups “just work”, while others do not.
These solutions would change mackup’s design philosophy a bit, true, but right now it is a choice between being more convenient and being more complete.
. I actually very much like that solution. Having mackup status work in such a way would allow mackup to function as usual, and would give a user the tools to understand the limitations of some cases right from the app. I’m all for it.

. It would also be useful in cases like this. What mackup decides to sync may not always be the best option, and when encountering these situations it would be way easier to make a personal fix, before contributing it to the project (where it’ll be a pain to everyone that has already synced those preferences incorrectly).
. > Also, without linking, if you forget to update one file, and you update the same file differently on another computer, you got a conflict.
You don’t, because the latest save will always trump the one before; we may have the trouble of losing some previous settings if we did not sync before (which is a bothersome one), but conflicts of files will not happen. On the other hand, conflicts happen now, and they’re harder to solve. As I mentioned before, when having more than one computer logged on at the same time, mackup frequently gets confused and we end up with a lot of versions of different conflicts on Dropbox.

But that's something worth considering as the field of conf files gets harder in the future, because of app store containers for example.

That’s my biggest point in this. When it’s a choice by using an app that takes a little extra work from time to time but does the job, and one that needs no intervention (except on errors, and those are arguably more probable and harder to fix) but does not do all the job, I believe, in this particular situation, that not having the frustration of having to care about those few configurations that it doesn’t handle, to be a superior offering.
In one option, if we don’t sync everything it’s our fault (we forgot), and we can always mitigate that (by setting up a regular script, maybe even directly on the terminal’s startup files). On the other, if we don’t fix everything, it’s the software’s fault, and this to me looks like a worse option — software is supposed to care for the best solutions. The former demands just a bit more, but can do everything, while the latter, while needing less work to setup, is also more limited. When building an app that deals with the peculiarities of all the other apps, and that will be so differently configured depending on the user, power trumps convenience.

The issue here seems to be how to convey to the user that some apps will have limited backup capabilities, so it is clear that those will need a bit more care to be kept up to date.
I don’t have a solution to this, but maybe the start of a suggestion. Since applications will essentially be divided into two groups (“always in sync” and “sync on demand”), maybe actually splitting them could help make that distinction (I’m thinking something to the effect of how homebrew uses taps). This way there would be an “opt-in” to these apps, making users aware of the why of this limitation.
Another option would be to only sync apps specified in the .mackup.cfg file, effectively forcing users to set it up, and be conscious about the limitations of certain cases (maybe apps would have to be organised under different sections of the file).
Both this options have the particularity of not making users worry about “is this app automatically synced, or do I have to do it myself regularly?”, since they’d be made aware of that when setting up, but they do come with the burden of requiring a bit extra work when initially setting up. I believe that initial hurdle to be more advantageous than having users puzzled about why some backups “just work”, while others do not.
These solutions would change mackup’s design philosophy a bit, true, but right now it is a choice between being more convenient and being more complete.

That’s my biggest point in this. When it’s a choice by using an app that takes a little extra work from time to time but does the job, and one that needs no intervention (except on errors, and those are arguably more probable and harder to fix) but does not do all the job, I believe, in this particular situation, that not having the frustration of having to care about those few configurations that it doesn’t handle, to be a superior offering.
In one option, if we don’t sync everything it’s our fault (we forgot), and we can always mitigate that (by setting up a regular script, maybe even directly on the terminal’s startup files). On the other, if we don’t fix everything, it’s the software’s fault, and this to me looks like a worse option — software is supposed to care for the best solutions. The former demands just a bit more, but can do everything, while the latter, while needing less work to setup, is also more limited. When building an app that deals with the peculiarities of all the other apps, and that will be so differently configured depending on the user, power trumps convenience.

So, same thing. If none of the core maintainers (you alone, I believe) is working on adding features, then the project is indeed effectively abandoned feature-wise. Wishing people contribute is very different than having said contributions.
. To be clear, I’m not criticising you not adding features. It’s your project, and as with the multiple ssh issues, it seems to me you have it working perfectly well for your exact needs and hence have no further incentive to keep adding to or changing it, which is totally valid.
That said, that is not what you’re saying. Issues are left to linger, and requests aren’t refused or responded to with “I won’t do it, but will accept a contribution for it”, so users rightly get the impression those things are indeed being taken into consideration and worked on, which is not the case.
. Most of that was addressed in my previous comments. Quite frankly, I have little interest in continuing down this conversation since I always make a huge effort to be respectful in pointing out what I think is wrong here but am always faced with what feels like a defensive take and answers to points I never made.
My take on it is (I believe) very clear: it is perfectly OK for you to not work on the project and everything that is asked, but you don’t say it. Issues are left open, including _numerous _duplicates without reply or acknowledgement for a long time (if ever). I’m certain there are capable users that would take on the work of submitting PRs for what is needed, but if you don’t participate (or better yet, lead) in the discussion of what you believe should be included _and how to implement it _why would anyone else?
PRs won’t happen simply because there’s a TODO. Contributors need to feel their ideas will be at the very least considered (even if immediately refused) and that there is a point to spending time on them. If you don’t participate, they never do, and move on.

. @jgeusebroek: I've definitely found it to be easier to create a new branch on your fork for each PR and never make commits on master. Once you push you can then go to your repo or the upstream repo and there are buttons at the top to create PRs for each branch. If you need to make tweaks for a PR you've already submitted you just make a commit on that branch and push and it ends up in the PR (that's what happened here). If you've ever tried using the 'Edit' buttons in the GH interface rather than cloning you'll find this is what it's doing, creating the branch (and fork if necessary) for you.
The really nice part and where it all came together for me is that once the branch on your fork is merged, you can simply delete it and GitHub even gives you a button to do so after a PR is merged. Then you don't have to keep rebasing/merging your master with upstream master.

. You should be able to fake it by creating $HOME/.dropbox/host.db with the right information.
python
host_db_path = os.environ['HOME'] + '/.dropbox/host.db'
https://github.com/lra/mackup/blob/master/mackup.py#L886-898
Mackup reads the second line of that file which should be a base64-encoded path to your Dropbox folder. The first line of my host.db is just 40 zeros. To get the base64 encoded version of your path you can run something like:
bash
python -c "import base64; print base64.b64encode('/Path/to/Dropbox/folder')"
Running the line above should result in something like:
L1BhdGgvdG8vRHJvcGJveC9mb2xkZXI=
So your completed host.db file if your path was actually /Path/to/Dropbox/folder would look like:
0000000000000000000000000000000000000000
L1BhdGgvdG8vRHJvcGJveC9mb2xkZXI=
. Actually I'm not sure how useful this is, the crashwatcher plist is definitely of questionable usefulness and the TotalTerminal plist just contains Sparkle prefs. So I'm closing this PR, I don't think having Mackup support for these two files is useful.

. @jgeusebroek: I've definitely found it to be easier to create a new branch on your fork for each PR and never make commits on master. Once you push you can then go to your repo or the upstream repo and there are buttons at the top to create PRs for each branch. If you need to make tweaks for a PR you've already submitted you just make a commit on that branch and push and it ends up in the PR (that's what happened here). If you've ever tried using the 'Edit' buttons in the GH interface rather than cloning you'll find this is what it's doing, creating the branch (and fork if necessary) for you.
The really nice part and where it all came together for me is that once the branch on your fork is merged, you can simply delete it and GitHub even gives you a button to do so after a PR is merged. Then you don't have to keep rebasing/merging your master with upstream master.

. You should be able to fake it by creating $HOME/.dropbox/host.db with the right information.
python
host_db_path = os.environ['HOME'] + '/.dropbox/host.db'
https://github.com/lra/mackup/blob/master/mackup.py#L886-898
Mackup reads the second line of that file which should be a base64-encoded path to your Dropbox folder. The first line of my host.db is just 40 zeros. To get the base64 encoded version of your path you can run something like:
bash
python -c "import base64; print base64.b64encode('/Path/to/Dropbox/folder')"
Running the line above should result in something like:
L1BhdGgvdG8vRHJvcGJveC9mb2xkZXI=
So your completed host.db file if your path was actually /Path/to/Dropbox/folder would look like:
0000000000000000000000000000000000000000
L1BhdGgvdG8vRHJvcGJveC9mb2xkZXI=

Tam-Lin:
Hi.  ~/Library/Quicklook (or, if shared between all users, /Library/QuickLook) is where Quicklook generators (the things that let you see a quick formatted version of a document by hitting the space bar instead of opening the document with the native command) are kept.  Similarly, ~/Library/Services and ~/Library/Scripts are where program services and program-specific applescripts are kept.  I'll admit that syncing the last two are possibly a bit iffy, as you could end up with scripts/services that invoke programs you don't have installed on a different computer, but I already sync them anyway.
. I'd say so, yes, or at least prompt to delete versus exiting.
. Not necessarily, though I thought that would be easiest.  Those files you mention are where you can set private settings, but the tool mainly manages things by moving files around.  Under the aliases, completions, and plugins directories, there are two subdirectories, ./available and ./enabled.  In order to enable something, files are moved around (or possibly links are created, I'm not sure, as I just run with the basic setup), so in order to have the settings match between two computers, you'd need to at least mirror all of those subdirectories.

On Thu, Jan 23, 2014 at 4:26 AM, Laurent Raufaste
notifications@github.com wrote:

Yeah sorry, I misread about the email.
Re what to do: Frankly I don't know, I never got the time to deeply think about it, and I don't want you to do something that's not gonna be used.
But in order to advance, I can tell you what I'm sure of: You can close this PR and create new ones:
- One per app for each app supported (or with improved support if it's already in, I remember having merged some from you)
- One for the custom apps feature. Whatever happens, this feature will be built and I'll merge your PR, or worst case, use your PR as a starting point.
  Regarding the feature, here are some thoughts:
- It can be a big json file containing all the apps, near the binary, or a bunch of small json files, one per app, in a dedicated folder.
- The actual json format used in mackup is simple (a list of path for each path) but it prevents us to do more, e.g. specify permissions for certain files, or specify files to exclude. It needs to be more specific and support future changes.
- Do we put the json in the same repo (like homebrew) or in a different repo, acting as a mac application database that can be worked on separately.
- What about ini or yaml as a file format ?
- The installer needs to be improved if mackup is not just one file anymore, homebrew is fine.
  There we go. If you create a new PR, feel free to paste/rephrase those questions, IMHO those need to be answered before starting the implementation.
  Thanks for digging this up ;)

aapit:
Any news on this? I installed Mackup a couple of days ago (through Homebrew) and this same error occurs. Already fixed some of the permissions (some files were owned by root), but haven't been able to do a complete backup yet. I have v0.5.4.
. I've tried removing ACL on the whole folder (chmod -RN), and chown'ing it to my own user. To no avail.
For now, I've worked around it by putting this in my ~/.mackup.cfg:
[Ignored Applications]
GNUPG
Also, Mackup tries to copy my private key files to Dropbox, unencrypted. As this is potentially incredibly sensitive data, I'm not so sure I want to store everything in Dropbox just like that.
. I think these files could be synced: gpg-agent.conf, gpg.conf. Perhaps also secring.gpg, trustdb.gpg, pubring.gpg, pubring.gpg~
Which leaves ignored: S.gpg-agent, private-keys-v1.d, random_seed
It's just a guestimate on what I have in my folder, combined with my personal preference of not storing private keys in Dropbox unencrypted. But I think ignoring the socket file (S.gpg-agent) would solve most of the problems.

. The .gem folder holds configuration information necessary for publishing ruby gems, like the credentials needed to to upload to rubygems.org
The .bundler folder holds configuration information for bundler. If you need special build instructions for a gem - maybe your MySQL, PostgreSQL or libxml is in a non-standard location - bundler persists that information in this folder. More info here: http://bundler.io/v1.3/man/bundle-config.1.html
Awesome Print is a Ruby library that pretty prints Ruby objects. Custom defaults can be saved in the file .aprc.

For some applications, this includes the license file. I have a private config for Alfred that I use together with the internal syncing in Alfred, and it works just fine. The stated point of Mackup is to be able to set up a new machine with a minimal amount of effort, then some syncable files in applications that offer internal syncing should be considered. For example, iTerm 2 is currently part of Mackup even though it includes internal syncing. I think https://github.com/lra/mackup/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md could use a little more consideration of these sorts of cases.
. lra has mentioned elsewhere the goal of supporting developers who use internal syncing as a means of encouraging purchases. That seems like a separate debate from whether Mackup syncing potentially breaks the internal syncing of an app. That would be the main difference between iTerms2 and Alfred2. I use the internal syncing of Keyboard Maestro because I figure the developer has given some thought on how best to use syncing.
. A proposal: https://github.com/lra/mackup/pull/406
. I've tested this out with a custom Mackup config. It doesn't work. Safari uninstalls on restart even with working links and with the extensions folder fully synced.
. This behavior led me to switch from TextMate to Sublime Text, which works very well under syncing. I could never figure out a custom syncing solution that didn't eventually break TextMate.
. Could you be more specific about what's not syncing, so I could try to reproduce it? Is ~/Library/Preferences/org.pqrs.Karabiner.plist linked?
. I can't reproduce this with Mackup 0.8.14 and Karabiner 10.21.0. Maybe Karabiner has a lock on the file while it is active. Try Mackup while Karabiner is not running.
I tried quitting Karabiner, deleting the preference files, and doing a Mackup restore. Then the Karabiner preference file symlinks are created and Karabiner works fine with them. Sorry I can't help more.
. This is probably a backup during plist editing: https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT202292 .
. Sorry, I only ever tested this with Python 3. @lra, what's the right way to fix the encoding? Is there a way to do it in the config, is this in the parser?
Also, it appears that Ubersicht might have a new default widgets directory ~/Library/Application Support/tracesOf.Uebersicht. Replacing the current directory with this in the config would fix the problem, but potentially break someone's older setup.. Follow the instructions for Configuration > Storage > File System, then set up git as you would for any project in specified directory.. I have it set up the same way. But you could write a shell script to run on a regular basis to commit and push your changes..

commadelimited:
I have the paid version of Alfred and I'd personally rather have all my configs in a single location. I was doing all of this myself, with a dotfiles repo on GitHub until I discovered Mackup.
. Email sent:

Greetings...
There exists a homebrew app called Mackup (https://github.com/lra/mackup/). It's a Python script which creates symlinks to the config/data files for a number of popular apps. It then copies those sources files into a Dropbox folder so that they can more easily be shared between computers.
An issue has been raised in the repo for Mackup specifically requesting support for Alfred. The author has asked that someone contact you (the creator of Alfred) for approval for Alfred to be added to Mackup.
https://github.com/lra/mackup/pull/127
Would you mind reviewing this pull request and commenting (if you have a Github account), or replying to me directly? I'll paste this email (and your reply) into the issue for the author's review.
Regards
Andy Matthews
A more than satisfied Alfred Powerpack user.
. Here's his response.

Hi Andy,
Alfred has quite a complex relationship with the Alfred.alfredpreferences package allowing for dynamic and live syncing between multiple Macs using the built-in [Powerpack] sync feature in Alfred's Advanced preferences. As such, I can't guarantee correct behaviour or forward compatibility if an external mechanism is used for syncing, so I wouldn't recommend it.
Cheers,
Andrew

==> Caveats
If you need Python to find the installed site-packages:
  mkdir -p ~/Library/Python/2.7/lib/python/site-packages
  echo '/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages' > ~/Library/Python/2.7/lib/python/site-packages/homebrew.pth
Perhaps this could be solved with the brew formula? cc/ @lra

==> Caveats

jonlong:
Would also love to know if anyone's got some advice on whether it's a bad move to store app preferences in a public repo, as I totally started coding this up without looking into that first :)
. Followup—just asked this question on #macdev and it sounds like storing prefs in a public repo is NOT a good idea. Pref files can store anything from personally identifiable info (phone numbers, addresses, etc) to auth info for less responsible apps.
I'm still interested in keeping these under version control for my own purposes, but it looks like a private repo + import script is the way to go.
. egh—screwing this all up. sorry! will clean up and resubmit.
EDIT: Cleaned, and reset. Sorry for the trouble! Back at 8c71a414f0691485bc67618222de772ae45c8fe7
. @vitorgalvao No, because #148 (as well as the current release) will store everything in a directory named "Mackup".  That PR adds the functionality to put that directory wherever you like. I was interested in a different dir name, so this PR allows you to rename it if you wish.
Totally agree re: naming. I did it that way because in mackup.py all directories are referred to as "folders", so I wanted to keep it consistent.
. Would also love to know if anyone's got some advice on whether it's a bad move to store app preferences in a public repo, as I totally started coding this up without looking into that first :)
. Followup—just asked this question on #macdev and it sounds like storing prefs in a public repo is NOT a good idea. Pref files can store anything from personally identifiable info (phone numbers, addresses, etc) to auth info for less responsible apps.
I'm still interested in keeping these under version control for my own purposes, but it looks like a private repo + import script is the way to go.

. Hi, @Joshfindit , maybe this comment can help you with cfgs.
. # Kinda solved this problem with mackup and ssh config backup / restore:
1) Reverted old backup of .ssh folder:
rm -rf ~/.ssh
mv ~/Dropbox/Mackup/.ssh ~/.ssh
2) Created ~/.mackup.cfg file and ~/.mackup folder
touch ~/.mackup.cfg && mkdir ~/.mackup
3) Downloaded two examples configs from docs into ~/.mackup folder
cd ~/.mackup
wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/lra/mackup/d0c26e605bf224c2b9194b88f9f777f8b00ac8e6/doc/.mackup/mackup.cfg
wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/lra/mackup/d0c26e605bf224c2b9194b88f9f777f8b00ac8e6/doc/.mackup/ssh.cfg
4) Run mackup backup
```
mackup backup
Backing up .ssh ...
Backing up .mackup ...
Backing up .mackup.cfg ...
```

Please test with your environment!
. My pleasure!

inonprince:
Thanks guys but I think it's something with my mac configuration rather than a specific issue with BTT or Forklift. My other mac doesn't do that when I open the apps.
. There is a way to reload settings for an app.
If after step #3, you'll open terminal and run the following command, everything works correctly:
defaults read [package_name]
so for Forklift, this is the command to run:
defaults read com.binarynights.ForkLift2
Another method is to kill cfprefsd for the current user (cfprefsd runs for the current user and for root. don't kill root's process).
. @Cottser This will not solve the issue. The cached data would still overwrite the (copied/linked) setting file.
. As a temporary solution i've created a quick php script and a launch agent that will bust the cache of updated files. seems to solve the issue.
https://www.dropbox.com/s/579je0k4wncme1i/clear_plist_cache.zip
- Unzip. Copy org.inon.cleanplistcache.plist to ~/Library/LaunchAgents/
- Edit the file and configure it:

WorkingDirectory    : The directory where clear_plist_cache.php is located
ProgramArguments[2] : Mackup's /Library/Preferences directory (usually /Users/USERNAME/Dropbox/Mackup/Library/Preferences)
WatchPaths[0]       : Mackup's /Library/Preferences directory
- Load the launch agent using "launchctl load ~/Library/LaunchAgents/org.inon.cleanplistcache.plist"
. It's a LunchAgent - It runs the script every time a file changes in /Users/[username]/Dropbox/Mackup/Library/Preferences
When the script runs, it'll find the files in the above directory that were modified since its last run. It'll run "defaults read [package_name]" for each of them.

So when you're modified the settings on one computer, dropbox will sync the files in your other computers, and each of your computers will run "default reads" for that file.
I'm using it for two weeks now, and it seems to work as far as I can tell. Not an optimal solution, though.

politicus:
@lra 
Some thought about this problem and mackup documentation. I discovered mockup on Twitter. Thought it was awesome. Installed it right away. 
Then, I tried to test it. I used forklift as my application to test. I wanted to know if shortcuts settings would sync. After 30 min of installing, reinstalling the app on my two macs, testing, hitting "mackup restore", configuring the .cfg file... I almost gave up as  nothing seemed to be working. Then I tried to test Witch shortcuts settings sync. Same results. 
Then I tried to test iTerm settings sync. I saw it was working perfectly well. Then I discovered this issue thread... "Happy" to know I was not the only one. But, (here is my point), I would have really appreciated knowing it before installing mackup. So including, applications specific issues in the README.md file would be we time-saving. 
I configured my .cfg file by copying and pasting the whole list of supported applications, excluding the 
one I didn't have. Now, that I am aware of this caching problem, in order to configure my .cfg file, I would exclude all the supported applications then add "tested and approved applications" to my list of applications to be sync. The problem is there is no list of "tested and approved applications". 
Summing it up, please inform your potential users of application specific potential/known issues in the README.md file and create a whitelisted applications file. I would had Forklift and Witch it. 
. I've spent a great deal of my time installing apps (productivity and dev oriented) these last weeks. 
I see a pattern. First look, "looks awesome" , download, install, test. Sometime, one hour or more later there is something, a very little thing, that makes the app not working for me (can't complete the installation tutorial, technical bug, not the right OS version, ...) Every time, it is pure period of time... mostly due to the fact I didn't have access to all the info I needed to know if installing the app was worth my time...
Yes, sure, lets drop the support for these apps. Let's built an application blacklist. And save people's time.

idolize:
I realize I'm new to this thread, but I just took a look at the PHP script posted by @inonprince, and it looks like a decent solution.
Why not rewrite it in Python and have mackup conditionally install the LaunchAgent script/plist if the user is running Mavericks? The makup installer could even generate the launchd plist dynamically using the variables/config already set up by mackup (so you don't need to manually specify the Dropbox/Google Drive/user home folders).
Seems like a very viable solution to fixing the issue of mackup in 10.9. The launchd agent can be installed/started without root access, requires no additional background processes (since the daemon is always running anyway), and because the script only runs on the WatchPaths dir it would run immediately whenever there is a change (so less overhead and more responsive than a program running as a cron job, as I've seen suggested in several of these Issue threads). Plus launchd is the Apple-sanctioned way of monitoring such things.
If nobody else is up to the task I'm happy to work on a pull request.
. @vitorgalvao Maybe I'm missing something, but how does the copy settings route solve this particular issue? Mavericks caches the settings, and the only way around that is via the defaults command- not changing the plist files on the file system alone (I've tried performing manual backups/restores by copying over plist files and it does not work in Mavericks without using defaults read).
Copying vs symlinking is an unrelated issue AFAIK; dealing with issues surrounding App Store apps' preferences.
. I see, so you're proposing a one-off sync command to copy/merge settings changes, but also run defaults to fix both the Mavericks and App Store issues in one go?
Personally I'd prefer linking if at all possible (don't aliases fix the App Store issue?), but I still see that as unrelated to the issue here: we can no longer rely purely on file changes to update preferences.
Frankly I don't understand the aversion to launchd, as it is not really running a command "periodically", but rather running the command whenever a preference file changes (the same thing Dropbox does currently). The difference is that we could run some additional code beyond Dropbox doing its client/server file sync routine.
Heck, even if we went with a one-off explicit "sync" command, the first thing I'd do is probably try to automate my machine to run the sync whenever my settings change via launchd so I don't have to remember to do it manually.

Joshfindit:
There's another 'paper cut' that something like this would solve:
Some apps, (Quicksilver, bettertouchtool, etc), use their folders a lot, and linking the config means that a) Dropbox's 'Recently Changed' feature is useless, and b) that Dropbox uses far more resources than necessary on each minor change.
One suggestion that's been bouncing around is to have a setting in the config for the backup interval and then either copy the files as suggested above, or create a zip file of the config, overwriting the old one.
Personally, I would rather the zip file because it keeps the file cruft down, while still giving Dropbox versioning.
Note: this feature could even be 'experts only', and require the user to either run the backup manually (mackup backup Quicksilver), or set up a cronjob themselves.
. I'm sad to report that in 10.11 Beta (15A234d), the color picker does not read custom color palettes when the ~/Library/Colors/ folder is symlinked.
To reproduce:
1. Open a file in Preview
2. Open the color picker (Show Markup Toolbar > Stroke or Fill > Show Colors... )
3. Go to the 'Color Palettes' tab
4. Create a new palette and add a couple colors
5. Quit Preview
6. Reopen Preview and verify that the palette is there
7. Quit preview
8. Go to ~/Library/Colors and see the custom palette (usually "Untitled.clr")
9. Move the Colors folder to ~/Dropbox/Mackup/Library/
10. in Terminal, run 'ln -s ~/Dropbox/Mackup/Library/Colors ~/Library/'
11. Verify that the alias is in ~/Library and that the .clr file is there
12. Open an image in Preview, and open the Color Picker
Expected result: The custom palette is listed and available
Actual result: The custom palette is missing, only the defaults are shown. Additionally, any newly created palettes are not saved.
. The file created by default on a case-insensitive system is ~/Library/Preferences/com.apple.dock.plist

Either add configurations like this that could cause confusion and/or visual cruft for some users, or;
find some other way to embrace them.
Realistically, there could be a wiki, a separate folder on the repo, etc. that documents anything that may be for a select few.

. There are two mackup-standard ways of doing this:
1. If it's application-specific, Create a new config file.
2. If it's a one-off, simply create the link yourself (copy the file to ~/Dropbox/destination, then ln -s ~/Dropbox/destination source)
. I propose that if the destination checks positive for being a symlink, then skip that one, do the rest, and warn/remind the user so they can resolve it and run restore again.
. Suggestion 1: change the file permissions on the file that you want to backup
Suggestion 2: hard link the root file to a location that's available to the user
. In a broader use-case;
What does a user do if they have 2, 3, or 20 custom configs?
It seems that it's required to back these up separately, and restore them before running mackup restore the first time.
. It's difficult to be clear about it (backing up the backup program's files?), so I'll run through mackup's main use-case:
Transitioning to a new computer

On the old computer

There are custom .cfg files for the specific setup, or for internal applications (Point being; they can't be in a mackup PR)
mackup backup is run, and links everything to Dropbox successfully

On the new computer

Install completes
Dropbox is installed and synced successfully
brew is installed, and brew install mackup installs mackup
mackup restore is run
The internal applications are not restored because the custom .cfg files are not present
. Previously, the way to run mackup was to git-clone locally, make changes, and use that. This works well for when your cloned repository is in Dropbox, and does allow for 'backing up' custom configs, but it's not ideal (and not the way recommended in the documentation).
. There's another 'paper cut' that something like this would solve:

Some apps, (Quicksilver, bettertouchtool, etc), use their folders a lot, and linking the config means that a) Dropbox's 'Recently Changed' feature is useless, and b) that Dropbox uses far more resources than necessary on each minor change.
One suggestion that's been bouncing around is to have a setting in the config for the backup interval and then either copy the files as suggested above, or create a zip file of the config, overwriting the old one.
Personally, I would rather the zip file because it keeps the file cruft down, while still giving Dropbox versioning.
Note: this feature could even be 'experts only', and require the user to either run the backup manually (mackup backup Quicksilver), or set up a cronjob themselves.
. I'm sad to report that in 10.11 Beta (15A234d), the color picker does not read custom color palettes when the ~/Library/Colors/ folder is symlinked.

mike-hearn:
I'd like to +1 this.
I use Mackup to backup my CodeKit license - this is the only thing I need backed up, with the purpose that when I mackup restore, it automatically adds the CodeKit license file so I don't need to re-enter my information.
The major downside here is that the license plist file also contains every other preference setting, including window size, so the file is getting overwritten constantly. This wastes Dropbox cycles, makes my "recent changes" pretty irrelevant, and so on. Essentially I don't care about the settings being constantly synced, I'd just like the license plist to be backed up once when I run mackup backup, and to be copied back to the proper place when I run mackup restore.
My ideal solution would be something like this:
[configuration]
copy = true
- On running mackup backup it just does a cp instead of an ln.
- On running mackup restore it does another cp instead of an ln.
I definitely think it's a common use-case for users to potentially want to back-up items (so they can be restored later), but not necessarily want them being persistently synced.

. Yes, a way to ignore files would add more complexity. 
On the other hand, listing exhaustively would make config longer, and in a way harder to maintain.
There is also another consequence of this decision.
The ability to ignore would mean that we can keep including the whole config directory, and new files that might appear in the future, would be included by default. This is what happens currently, because for most apps the whole config folder is being included.
Without a way to ignore certain files, some applications will be different, because instead of having the whole folder included, they will have only certain specific files. This means those apps won't have new config files added automatically.
It seems dangerous to me to include new files by default, and I think ideally only files, and not directories, should be allowed to be included. However that would require much more work from part of the developers.
So if we want to keep the ability to add whole folders, I'm in favor of an option to ignore. It would allow consistency between apps, in the sense that all can have the whole config folder included, and therefore new files added by default.

So even if blacklisting was implemented it would only be a layer of abstraction and wouldn’t have the benefits of auto including new files.

There is a problem though: If you want dir to be synced, you can't ask mackup to not sync dir/file because of the way we sync things: we link the dir directory in your storage and cannot unlink a file in a linked dir. So in your case, the only option I see would be to change the config of the 2 applications listed from listing 1 dir to listing an explicit list of files to sync.
Right ?

thejase-snippets:
Package Control installs its sourced packages in ../Installed Packages.  ./Packages is for custom packages or overrides, and thus should be included by mackup by default.  I'd like to request that this behavior be reinstated.
. Doesn't this require me to change the behavior myself?  I'm a user, not a dev.  Not familiar with the inner workings.  Can this particular behavior just be reverted to it's original intent?
. Great.  Thank you.  Let me see if I can explain further:
Sublime Text has the following structure for Package Control (PC) + Settings
- Installed Packages: This is where a pristine, source-controlled Package Control package is installed.  They are zipped up and given .sublime-package extensions.  These don't need to be backed up with mackup, as Package Control will handle this
- Packages: This is where non-PC packages are stored.  This is where someone might create their own package or install one manually. This should be backed up
  - User: This is where overrides reside for both Installed Packages and Packages.  
Currently, mackup is only backing up the User folder.  Previously (at least in version 0.5), it was backing up the Packages folder (which includes the User folder).  The previous setup was appropriate.

. I don't think that's really how mackup works. It doesn't run as a background process and mackup backup is just run to symlink all your conf files. Mackup could just add .atom/packages.list to its mackup config but this is just a suggested way to do things from a comment thread. You could do pretty much the same with any package manager, so not sure that is right to add to mackup itself. Others may disagree.
I would suggest just adding a custom mackup config to your ~/.mackup directory like this.
. Personally, I think it's still useful. You still get all your regular config files synced.

. With the latest version im finally able to backup including Atom. I still think the sync should be a bit more selective for this app, because it does include a large files amount, including caching folders that keeps Dropbox syncing all day while we work with the app. 
I believe the compile-cache, .node-gyp and storage all seem to be temporary or cache related and should be excluded. 
This also because, not sure if it is your experience, but to me it seems that Dropbox have some issues of performance and memory consumption when you have large quantities of files being synced.
Thanks.
. Sorry for the "spamming", just to confirm my theory:
http://discuss.atom.io/t/node-gyp-in-atom/5742
. @damiankloip Can I overpower the default Atom config that comes with Mackup using what is described here, will I run into trouble afterwards?
. I could do a PR for that, but since I can't override the "builtin" config I wouldn't have a way to test it actually works.
The changes I was looking for are quite simple though. Sync everything except the following folders:
.atom/.node-gyp
.atom/compile-cache
.atom/storage
All of those contains temporary and cache information that not only are dispensable for the sync process, but also are contributing for a lot unneeded sync activity in Dropbox because they change while you work with the editor.
. I can confirm you can safely ignore:
storage
compile-cache
dev
.npm
.node-gyp
At this point I will disable Mackup's sync Atom, it is causing me issues. Hope this may be added in a future update to Mackup.
Thank you.

. With the latest version im finally able to backup including Atom. I still think the sync should be a bit more selective for this app, because it does include a large files amount, including caching folders that keeps Dropbox syncing all day while we work with the app. 
I believe the compile-cache, .node-gyp and storage all seem to be temporary or cache related and should be excluded. 
This also because, not sure if it is your experience, but to me it seems that Dropbox have some issues of performance and memory consumption when you have large quantities of files being synced.
Thanks.
. Sorry for the "spamming", just to confirm my theory:
http://discuss.atom.io/t/node-gyp-in-atom/5742
. @damiankloip Can I overpower the default Atom config that comes with Mackup using what is described here, will I run into trouble afterwards?
. I could do a PR for that, but since I can't override the "builtin" config I wouldn't have a way to test it actually works.
The changes I was looking for are quite simple though. Sync everything except the following folders:
.atom/.node-gyp
.atom/compile-cache
.atom/storage
All of those contains temporary and cache information that not only are dispensable for the sync process, but also are contributing for a lot unneeded sync activity in Dropbox because they change while you work with the editor.
. I can confirm you can safely ignore:
storage
compile-cache
dev
.npm
.node-gyp
At this point I will disable Mackup's sync Atom, it is causing me issues. Hope this may be added in a future update to Mackup.
Thank you.

. I would not recommend adding this as a default functionality on mackup. If those keychain files become corrupted, they can bring an entire system to it's knees, requiring a full restore from scratch.
If this is something that you want to implement for yourself, I'd recommend making a custom config for it.
. +1 :+1: 
I actually have a modded sublime text config for mackup that does this, and I ignore the default config. Works flawlessly. 
. There is also a workaround posted in #350 now. Are you still experiencing this problem?
. I'm a little confused about the intended purpose of this change. It sounds as though it adds an extra step to the user workflow, but I'm not 100% clear on that. Can you elaborate?
I also would agree that the command terminology is confusing. I really like the idea of mackup link and mackup unlink instead of mackup backup and mackup uninstall. But, I would argue that changing these commands could be made directly to the current functionally of mackup without any code changes needed.
What would be the new workflow of mackup backup and mackup link in the scenario you are proposing?
I'd also like to add to a couple of things mentioned in the initial post: 
First, Dropbox has it's own private version control. If you delete something, it is immediately recoverable through the web interface, so maybe it would be good to add that to the README.
Second, Dropbox is merely one of the options for file storage. If it does not work for your personal workflow, you are free to define a standard file system directory. Is perhaps the need here that you would like it to back up to BOTH dropbox AND a file system directory?

. Technically neither are "correct," they're just based on preference. You could theoretically name the file .nancypants and as long as you execute the command ...
git config --global core.excludesfile ~/.nancypants
... It will serve as your global ignore. I think maybe the ~/.gitignore_global filename convention is actually Github's fault, which might make it more common, but not necessarily "standard."
I think this perhaps speaks to whether or not a code change should be made to mackup directly, or whether a user should be responsible for custom configuration files that are not a universal standard. 
If we were to get explicitly technical about it, mackup should be reconfigured to only backup ~/.config/git/ignore which is the documented default global ignore file.
Source: http://git-scm.com/docs/gitignore

I'd also like to add to a couple of things mentioned in the initial post: 
First, Dropbox has it's own private version control. If you delete something, it is immediately recoverable through the web interface, so maybe it would be good to add that to the README.
Second, Dropbox is merely one of the options for file storage. If it does not work for your personal workflow, you are free to define a standard file system directory. Is perhaps the need here that you would like it to back up to BOTH dropbox AND a file system directory?

techniq:
After this change it is no longer possible to restore your installed packages.  Atom doesn't keep a list of installed packages, but you can generate one using apm list --installed --bare > packages.list and then restore them using apm installcat packages.list``
There is also a package to manage packages - https://github.com/Hackafe/atom-sync-settings which I'm using now until Mackup handles packages correctly
It doesn't appear there is a way to restore your packages now after this change.  Atom doesn't keep a package.json 
. I don't know if mackup can, but it would be best if it could run apm list --installed --bare > packages.list on mackup backup and then run apm installcat packages.list`.  The problem is (as far as I know) Atom doesn't persist to disk the list of packages beyond the actual installed directories, which causes all the problems (and are really heavy to backup all those assets)
. I don't think removing Atom support is needed, as there is still use in getting the config, keymaps, styles, etc.   I was just bring up the fact before #451, performing amackup backup, delete~/.atomand thenmackup restore`, your editor would be stored before blowing away the directory.  Now, all your packages are lost (which is a big deal IMO).  
I think @damiankloip suggestion for custom custom config is the way to go (for now).  After doing https://gist.githubusercontent.com/damiankloip/b4ea46db79c5f125861d/raw/c4013615bc5ed6da85ff36fc09dd6f16c4925f2e/atom-extra.cfg > ~/.mackup/atom-extra.cfg, the following workflow should be possible.
- apm list --installed --bare > packages.list && mackup backup
- mackup restore && apm installcat packages.list. After this change it is no longer possible to restore your installed packages.  Atom doesn't keep a list of installed packages, but you can [generate](https://discuss.atom.io/t/how-to-backup-all-your-settings/15674) one using `apm list --installed --bare > packages.list` and then restore them using `apm install `cat packages.list
There is also a package to manage packages - https://github.com/Hackafe/atom-sync-settings which I'm using now until Mackup handles packages correctly
It doesn't appear there is a way to restore your packages now after this change.  Atom doesn't keep a package.json 
. I don't know if mackup can, but it would be best if it could run apm list --installed --bare > packages.list on mackup backup and then run apm installcat packages.list`.  The problem is (as far as I know) Atom doesn't persist to disk the list of packages beyond the actual installed directories, which causes all the problems (and are really heavy to backup all those assets)
. I don't think removing Atom support is needed, as there is still use in getting the config, keymaps, styles, etc.   I was just bring up the fact before #451, performing amackup backup, delete~/.atomand thenmackup restore`, your editor would be stored before blowing away the directory.  Now, all your packages are lost (which is a big deal IMO).  
I think @damiankloip suggestion for custom custom config is the way to go (for now).  After doing https://gist.githubusercontent.com/damiankloip/b4ea46db79c5f125861d/raw/c4013615bc5ed6da85ff36fc09dd6f16c4925f2e/atom-extra.cfg > ~/.mackup/atom-extra.cfg, the following workflow should be possible.
- apm list --installed --bare > packages.list && mackup backup
- mackup restore && apm installcat packages.list``

. From the README

Bullsh*t, what does it really do to my files
Let's take git as an example. Your settings for git are saved in your home
folder, in the .gitconfig file.
Backup
If you have Dropbox, these things happen when you launch mackup backup:
1. cp ~/.gitconfig ~/Dropbox/Mackup/.gitconfig
2. rm ~/.gitconfig
3. ln -s ~/Dropbox/Mackup/.gitconfig ~/.gitconfig
Now your git config is always backed up and up to date on all your workstations.

It symlinks files because the point is to sync a single folder between machines once, and then to forget it. If it copied files you'd have to manually overwrite your older copies every time you update something on one machine.

. I'm convinced now @yonkeltron: the issue you're seeing is definitely unrelated and I see it too.  Here's what's happening: the atom.cfg was updated at some point to NOT backup the full ~/.atom directory.  Instead, it only lists specific files under that directory.  My ~/.atom directory is a symlink to my dropbox directory.  So, when I run 'mackup backup', the new atom.cfg is not considering the fact that the .atom directory is a symlink itself and is trying to create symlinks for the individual files instead.
To work around the problem, break the symlink of ~/.atom to your dropbox directory, then a 'mackup backup' will 'do the right thing'.  Not sure if this is the best behavior of mackup, but the workaround is quick and easy.
Here's me fixing it on my notebook:
$ rm ~/.atom
    $ mv ~/Dropbox/Mackup/.atom ~
    $ mackup backup
    Backing up .atom/init.coffee...
    Backing up .atom/snippets.cson...
    Backing up .atom/config.cson...
    Backing up .atom/styles.less...

. I'm convinced now @yonkeltron: the issue you're seeing is definitely unrelated and I see it too.  Here's what's happening: the atom.cfg was updated at some point to NOT backup the full ~/.atom directory.  Instead, it only lists specific files under that directory.  My ~/.atom directory is a symlink to my dropbox directory.  So, when I run 'mackup backup', the new atom.cfg is not considering the fact that the .atom directory is a symlink itself and is trying to create symlinks for the individual files instead.
To work around the problem, break the symlink of ~/.atom to your dropbox directory, then a 'mackup backup' will 'do the right thing'.  Not sure if this is the best behavior of mackup, but the workaround is quick and easy.
Here's me fixing it on my notebook:
$ rm ~/.atom
    $ mv ~/Dropbox/Mackup/.atom ~
    $ mackup backup
    Backing up .atom/init.coffee...
    Backing up .atom/snippets.cson...
    Backing up .atom/config.cson...
    Backing up .atom/styles.less...
    Backing up .atom/keymap.cson...

```
import os
from fnmatch import fnmatch
ignore_list = ['f.lux']
files = os.listdir('/Users/leo/Library/ColorSync/Profiles/')
for filename in files:
    if any(fnmatch(filename, pattern) for pattern in ignore_list):
        print('Ignore', filename)
        continue
```
