. I'm definitely being challenged with the reality of the symlink functionality and may have to stop using mackup until it does backups rather than symlinks.
Let me give you an an example, I have the app Sizeup that helps manage my windows. But I have multiple screen types and dimensions, so I have bash code that does thing like:
if [ `system_profiler SPDisplaysDataType | grep 'Cinema\|Thunderbolt' | wc -l` -eq "1" ]; then
    # Give room on right to show icons
    defaults write com.irradiatedsoftware.SizeUp MarginRight 220
else #we are on laptop screen
  # On laptop, fill screen
  defaults write com.irradiatedsoftware.SizeUp MarginRight 0
fi
The problem is that when this code is run on a laptop, it changes the setting on my desktop, and vise versa. So often neither are correct.
Since this is commercial software, what I thought mackup would offer me is the ability to deal with serial numbers and other stuff I could not put in my public dotfiles repository https://github.com/christophera/dotfiles — but configuration info is also put into these same files, causing the problem.
-- Christopher Allen
.

ini

engine = dropbox
directory = backup/mackup

Geogi:
I'd like to weight on that. The GnuPG directory should not be copied either.
EDIT: now that I think about it, shipping a .mackup.cfg file disabling those packages, along with a note in the README saying they're supported but disabled by default is a much simpler option.
~~The best would be to have a "enabled" / "disabled" flag on configuration files and an action for the cli to switch between the two. Sensitive applications would be disabled by default but users that want them (e.g. local backups) could enable them easily.~~
~~If it's not worth the effort, I would suggest to simply remove SSH and GnuPG (and anything else that's sensitive) from the list of supported apps. This is not a sane default.~~
The tool is great though :-)

RickWong:
This should be a no-brainer. You don't mess with someone's privates unless they consent to it.
. Difference is that ssh keys are keys -- NOT config. That would be .ssh/config. For some users syncing ssh keys can indeed be convenient. The question here is: Should mackup sync keys by opt-out (default) or by opt-in?
Personally I found it rather unpleasant to discover that Dropbox* obtained my ssh key only because I used ls -lah to view the backup dir. Only after that discovery did I find this issue on Github. Had to go replace my ssh keypairs everywhere.
- I trust Dropbox, but not this much!

crkochan:
If the goal is to backup the (possibly cached) preferences plist file, then the path should be Library/Containers/com.codeux.irc.textual/Data/Library/Preferences/com.codeux.irc.textual.plist.
As-is, the current configuration of pointing to Library/Containers/com.codeux.irc.textual is in not specific enough, and ends up pulling in too much unrelated data. In my case this is >20GB of stuff that I don't want mackup to handle.

Gyran:
Order is important because in file https://github.com/lra/mackup/blob/master/mackup/appsdb.py#L27 you don't know in which order the files will be iterated. Therefore the config file in ~/.mackup might be iterated before the config file in applications and your custom config won't override the included config file.

flyinghyrax:
Just wanted to chime in that I have seen this problem on my system - adding new configs in ~/.mackup/ works for me but overriding them hasn't so far (for vim and ssh at least), and I think this is the cause.  Because get_config_files() returns a set, the files are iterated in an indeterminate order, so user defined configs may work, but not necessesarily.
I don't imagine that filtering dups out of the list before returning it would introduce too much overhead.

acusti:
I wouldn’t mind mackup backing up my QuickLook plugins (sounds practical for bootstrapping a new machine), but I’d also be happy continuing to manage them with homebrew-cask.
That said, I originally used brew cask myself to install my QuickLook plugins (which I discovered via this repo). Homebrew-cask leaves the existing ~/Library/QuickLook directory and adds the individual .qlgenerator files to the folder as symlinks. My QuickLook plugins then stopped working after mackup took them over. I have to manually remove or rename the mackup Quicklook symlink (incidentally, it should be camel case, i.e. QuickLook) and restore my previous version of the folder, then run qlmanage -r in order to get them working again. And I have confirmed that the issue is specific to the plugins that were installed by brew cask, because I had one additional QuickLook plugin that I manually installed by copying it to the QuickLook folder, and that plugin still worked with mackup’s symlinked folder.
Maybe mackup could detect if the QuickLook plugins are already being managed by brew cask before taking over in order to avoid breaking anything? I don’t really have any idea what the best solution is. I suppose the simplest thing is to just remove support as @ponychicken suggests, but I’m not sure that’s ideal.
. @revolter Nice! I just set up a new computer recently and couldn’t figure out why my quicklook plugins weren’t working, then I realized it was from this issue. Thanks for the tip!

. @jnv Packages/User only contains the settings for the installed packages, and not the packages themselves. light94:
Hello!
After browsing the source code for Mackup, i've found that it was written in python2.x . Your system seems to have a default installation of python3 where print is a _function , so you are getting this error. You can use python's 2to3 tool to solve this problem . Just run _$ 2to3 -w main.py and it will be adapted to python3

After installing mackup and running mackup backup, textmate throws the following error: "Failure running 'Comment Selection'. env: ruby 18: Permission Denied". Unfortunately, mackup uninstall, does not restore textmate to its original state. Not sure why mackup would symlink textmate's ruby directory, but in any case, only solution I found was as follows:
shell
mackup uninstall
brew uninstall mackup
brew cask zap textmate
brew cask install textmate

jrk:
+1 this is a huge problem for me. It breaks a very large number of core TextMate operations.
. The issue seems to be that sync services aren't always preserving the execute permission bits on synced files. The more direct fix is:
bash
$ cd Mackup/Library/Application Support/TextMate/Managed/Bundles/Bundle Support.tmbundle/Support/shared/bin
$ chmod +x *. +1 this is a huge problem for me. It breaks a very large number of core TextMate operations.
. The issue seems to be that sync services aren't always preserving the execute permission bits on synced files. The more direct fix is:
bash
$ cd Mackup/Library/Application Support/TextMate/Managed/Bundles/Bundle Support.tmbundle/Support/shared/bin
$ chmod +x *.

devnulled:
@lra -- yes, it would probably be problematic with Flux if it does create new files over and over.  To be honest that sounds like kind of a hack for what the profiles are supposed to be used for, though.
I'm not sure of a way to exclude the flux files unless they follow a standard naming convention?
I do actually use this to sync monitor settings across different machines.  IE-- I have two laptops, a work laptop and a home laptop.  I use a piece of hardware to setup and tune every monitor I have, then I sync those profiles across my machines.  I need this because I'm a photographer and my color settings need to be consistent across monitors and printers.
. Thanks @Joshfindit.  I'll go ahead and make a fix to ignore the "f.lux" directory.
. Actually I forgot there isn't a way to ignore paths yet.  Fixing this ticket depends on #602.
. @ponychicken
Was randomly thinking about this bug again today.  Until #602 is closed, I'd suggest adding ColorSync to [applications_to_ignore] in your own mackup config.  See the docs for more on how to do that.
I think this is sort of an edge case because the way that Flux applies its color settings is kind of a hack.  However I will fix it whenever #602 is implemented.

modest:
I'd love it, but it's hard.  App-specific overrides ("App Shortcuts" tab) are stored in the preferences file for each individual app.  OS X inserts a NSUserKeyEquivalents dictionary into the plist of every single app that you edit.  Kind of a crazy solution, but I can see the rationale.
So, you could take a few different approaches:
- Wait for each app to be individually supported by mackup, and include their Preferences plist (most already do.) This will include your overrides. For example, Spotify's mackup configuration includes the plist.
- Add a new engine to mackup to backup keyboards shortcuts separately.  You would probably need to crawl through the user's Preferences folder for plist's, extract the NSUserKeyEquivalents dictionary from each plist, and store them in some centralized file. (Then, on restore, you'd need to inject those back into the plist files of every app.)
- Just backup all Preferences.
In my opinion, mackup is currently optimized for non-standard settings files, such as command line tools.  If mackup wants to back up the settings & data of all well-behaved GUI apps, too, there are potentially some better automatic approaches that don't require manual work (custom config files) for every single app.  That might be treading too dangerously close to a fully-functional system backup tool, though.

. Solved my own issue, sort of. I didn't realize that mackup already has configs for backing up ~/.config/fish and ~/.config/oh-my-fish, so my custom rule for the whole ~/.config was mucking things up.
. You're right, I may be a bit overzealous about mackup. My reasoning is that
1. Git is extremely popular and common amongst the kind of user that would setup mackup (more so than say iterm2, adobe, etc
2. There's already a git cfg dir in mackup, might as well make it more complete. I think a global git ignore is a very common setting. Often when I switch machines it leads to accidental commits of garbage files because I don't have all the random junk that was incrementally appended to my global gitignore in the past.
3. Googling for "global gitignore" almost certainly returns this github article (w and w/out personalized search results), which demos ~/.gitignore_global. The majority of global gitignore users most likely reference that article or simply go with ~/.gitignore as is the convention for project-based ignores according to the git docs.
. Yes!

joeyhoer:
I'm seeing this exact same issue.
On a machine that already has applications installed, but where mackup has not yet run. I get the No such file or directory error for the  applications that are not in the back up (or are only installed on the "new" machine).
@aristidesfl, I agree that mackup should check to see if the files exist in the backup before trying to restore them.
. Good catch.
You may be right. I think mackup was run on the machine I was referencing earlier, and then the backup was overwritten, so there may have been broken symlinks. Which kinda makes more sense as to why this is breaking.
Your command works beautifully. To explain why it works (for future readers), the script searches the current user's Library directory for all symlinks (-type l), but before it does that, it traverses all symbolic links (-L). According to the find manual, "If the referenced file does not exist, the file information and type will be for the link itself." So it only returns the broken links. The rest of the command escapes spaces in filenames and then removes the files~~, though, doing so in that way seems unnecessary as find has a builtin -delete flag~~. This is necessary because the find -delete flag is forbidden when symlinks are followed.
The following command will accomplish the same thing without the use of sed:
find -L . -type l -exec rm {} \;
. You're right. I've amended the explanation above.
. This is true. It appears that commit was added in April whereas the last release (0.8.5) was released in March. If you want support/access to that specific feature/commit, you'll have to use the HEAD version.
. A possible solution - https://github.com/joeyhoer/mackup/tree/feature/611-app-args.
Not fully baked and introduces some backwards compatibility issues.
. If we implement a solution, we will probably also want to include command line "autocomplete" functionality (although to do this for different shells may be complex), or a search function, so users can find the "exact string" which is required.

reitermarkus:
This happened to me too. Then I tried deleting my unused preferences in Dropbox, but forgot that I had the (now broken) symlinks in my Library.
I cleaned out all broken symlinks with this (use at your own risk):
find -L ~/Library -type l | sed -e 's/\ /\\\ /' | xargs rm
After this, mackup restore went through without any error.
Of course, this is only a temporary solution.
. Thanks for the added information. I found the command with the -delete flag first, but it said this isn't supported for symlinks, at least not on OS X.
. I can also confirm this works, I have been using this for about a year now without any issues.
. It's still working for me.

nkgm:
It appears it's keeping its preferences along with Finder in ~/Library/Preferences/com.apple.finder.plist, so this becomes a matter of also adding Finder to the list of supported apps. Is there a reason it's not already there? Also, how does mackup deal with cfprefsd and Preference caching?
. I am, once I get a chance, but I'm not sure how to make this reliable. In my experience, you need to killall cfprefsd before you restore the .plist, or else Finder will overwrite it with its current preferences when you restart it. I'm not even sure it makes sense to have a shared dropbox folder between two machines as the result may become unpredictable. In my own setup, it makes more sense to have a ~/Dropbox/Mackup/macbook-work, a ~/Dropbox/Mackup/macmini-home, and copy between the two under controlled conditions. @lra what do you think?
. Using 0.8.10 now.
I must have done something really nasty while experimenting (like renaming the ~/Dropbox/Mackup folder after a "backup everything" run), so it was due to orphaned symlinks. I've reproduced the condition, and running with verbose is very informative, yet it reports orphaned symlinks as does not exist. I know it's an edge case, but a more detailed message would be useful if you ever get yourself into this type of situation.
. I'm still getting to know mackup, so I'm not sure what would make better sense in that situation. I can tell you it was definitely confusing to a newcomer such as myself, but once you get the gist of mackup you shouldn't hit that condition. Maybe something neutral such as does not exist (broken symlink), possibly implying mackup backup or mackup restore has already run and something bad happened to your dropbox files. rkpatel33:
The issues was being caused my a link I had set manually to Dropbox from my previous system for keeping thing synced. Deleting it solved the problem.
Apparently the restore command does not anticipate that possibility.
. My scenario was just the following. Before running mackup restore the state of my sublime user settings folder was:
[ST3 location].../Packages/User -> [some old manually set location on dropbox via symlink]
Running mackup restore threw the error above. My solution to the issue was to
$ rm [ST3 location].../Packages/User
Then
$mackup restore
And all worked fine, it linked [ST3 location].../Packages/User to my settings that had already been synced to my Dropbox/mackup folder from my primary computer.
. Just did a brew install this week, version 0.8.5 looks like. But didn't see
that message. Odd.

Rishi K. Patel

I've been dogfooding a custom configuration — with a symlinked Terminal preference file — on three different machines synced to Dropbox since I submitted the pull request and haven't had any issues.
The symlink is still intact and working after three OS X system point releases and three months of testing.
I'm surprised there hasn't been more interest in this pull request though, given the popularity of Apple's built-in terminal app. All machines have been running Mac OS X 10.11.x "El Capitan".

bdlow:
As of 10.12.6 (and I suspect earlier), Terminal replaces the symlink with a copy of the file. i.e. mackup's approach can't work for the plist file.
```
% sw_vers    
ProductName:    Mac OS X
ProductVersion: 10.12.6
BuildVersion:   16G29
% mackup restore
Restoring Library/Preferences/com.apple.Terminal.plist ...
You already have a file named Library/Preferences/com.apple.Terminal.plist in your home.
Do you want to replace it with your backup ? yes
% readlink ~/Library/Preferences/com.apple.Terminal.plist
/Users/ben/Google Drive/Mackup/Library/Preferences/com.apple.Terminal.plist
```
- Terminal > Quit
- reopen Terminal
% readlink ~/Library/Preferences/com.apple.Terminal.plist 
% ls -l ~/Library/Preferences/com.apple.Terminal.plist
-rw-------  1 ben  staff  17454  8 Oct 21:48 /Users/ben/Library/Preferences/com.apple.Terminal.plist
It doesn't even like hard links:
```
% rm /Users/ben/Library/Preferences/com.apple.Terminal.plist

24004388 -rw-------  2 ben  staff  17454  8 Oct 21:06 /Users/ben/Library/Preferences/com.apple.Terminal.plist

rm "/Users/anzumana/Library/Preferences/com.googlecode.iterm2.plist"
mackup restore
. It would be a nice to have if mackup would remove links in the restore process IF the target does not exist anymore.

https://github.com/clvv/fasd/blob/master/fasd#L371

. Hi @SharkIng 
Since my PR to fasd is still not merged, I can share a simple work around, you can just create a .fasdrc file with:
FASD_DATA="$HOME/.fasd/fasd"
then if you move the .fasd data files to a directory, fore example like this:
mkdir ~/tmpdir
mv ~/.fasd ~/tmpdir/fasd
mv ~/tmpdir ~/.fasd
the whole folder will be symlinked.. It is used by audacious plugin supporting lastfm (http://www.last.fm) scrobbler. This file is not generated if you do not use the plugin. If you do and are offline, the scrobbles are stored in this file and are pushed to lastfm once you are online again.

dirkdirk:
It helps to know what's really going on to fix this issue, so read this: what it really does
Now you understand that macup moves the dot files to the storage of your choice, then creates a sym link to said dot file.
To manually remove a specific app after it's already been mackup'd.
Add the app name to ignore list (supported apps listed on home page) with $ vim /.mackup.cfg
Open iCloud Drive in Finder.
Find where app's files are kept in /Mackup.
Copy them back to local machine in the right places.
Run: $ mackup backup, answer y at the prompts.
Look on iCould Drive to ensure the app's files aren't there.
This process worked for Atom for me (I'm using Atom package Sync-settings package).
If anyone sees/knows of any shortcoming of this method, please let us know!

ursbraem:
I'm not sure if I get this right: if I want mackup (thanks!) to sync my atom packages too, I need to add the packages.cson to .mackup.cfg? 
My Config file (in my_settings/Mackup and with a symlink that Mackup probably created at the first run in the home dir) now looks like this:
```
[storage]
engine = file_system
path = my_settings
[configuration_files]
~/.atom/packages.cson
```
Should that work (it hasn't done so yet) and is it required to add that line to sync atom packages?
. Ok, of course the packages list has to exist before you can sync it.
Create it with https://atom.io/packages/package-sync or apm list --installed --bare > packages.cson (cf. https://discuss.atom.io/t/installed-packages-list-into-single-file/12227)
To install the packages in that list on the second system, I understand that you have to use apm install --packages-file packages.cson then
. Also, if you want to add custom config files for an app, in my case atom, I understood that you have to create ~/.mackup/atom.cfg, copy over everything from https://github.com/lra/mackup/blob/master/mackup/applications/atom.cfg to that file, and then add your desired additionoal files.
Seems to work now!
So: To sync atom packages:
- Make atom write a list of installed packages with apm list --installed --bare > packages.cson or similar
- teach mackup to sync them with a custom .cfg file
- install packages on synced devices with install --packages-file packages.cson
PS for others: while this looks all good, I haven't got the manual install to work yet, will now try the "star" method from https://discuss.atom.io/t/installed-packages-list-into-single-file/12227. Not mackup's fault though.

cappadona:
Thanks @ursbraem...big help. Instead of overriding mackup's default atom.cfg, I just added a separate config file for keeping packages in sync, as described in the docs.
~/.mackup/atom-packages.cfg
```
[application]
name = Atom Packages
[configuration_files]
.atom/packages.cson
``. Thanks @ursbraem...big help. Instead of overriding mackup's defaultatom.cfg`, I just added a separate config file for keeping packages in sync, as described in the docs.

iainbeeston:
This is irritating, it seems the default for pip install is different on debian-based versions of linux. Here's what I get on ubuntu:
pip install --help | grep system
  --system                    Install using the system scheme (overrides
                              --user on Debian systems)
Seems like either the default is --user on debian, or at least the --system option only exists on debian. Perhaps there should be separate install instructions for debian/ubuntu?
. Sorry for the delay, I've looked into this further now, and it seems that ubuntu actually patches pip to change the default to install user-locally (not globally), so it's only on ubuntu that users need to use the --system flag (see here)
I've updated the wording to reflect that. I think this should be ok to merge now?

bbohling:
While I have not used this app, I am exploring so have read the documentation (including the config stuff). This is my understanding:

Do I have to do anything to keep them in sync or they will do everything automatically?

No, mackup backup copies the app file(s) to a central location (e.g., Dropbox) and then creates a symlink (virtual link to the central location). As long as each computer you use mackup on has the same central service (e.g., Dropbox), the files will stay in sync. These are the supported storage services.

If I install a new app, is the preference automatically backuped or do I have to do something?

No. You will have to run mackup backup again. If mackup supports the app, it will copy the preferences to the central location.. While I have not used this app, I am exploring so have read the documentation (including the config stuff). This is my understanding:

No. You will have to run mackup backup again. If mackup supports the app, it will copy the preferences to the central location..

. OK I think I know why it happens.
For some reason certain stuff related to the .git folder was symlinked to files belonging to GitHub's mac app. I have no clue why this has happened in the first page, but removing those symlinks (that point to a file that no longer exists) solves the issue. You can do this manually but in some cases you can just delete the whole local git repo and clone it again to put the proper files in the .git folder back in place.
Once I did this the problem was solved.

. OK I think I know why it happens.
For some reason certain stuff related to the .git folder was symlinked to files belonging to GitHub's mac app. I have no clue why this has happened in the first page, but removing those symlinks (that point to a file that no longer exists) solves the issue. You can do this manually but in some cases you can just delete the whole local git repo and clone it again to put the proper files in the .git folder back in place.
Once I did this the problem was solved.
Example .git folder where the issue occurred:

erch:
I have also the issue with Python 3 on a linux machine.
The error occurs because the configuration file applications/ubersicht.cfg contains a Ü and my host is configured to use UTF-8.
As a quick fix I changed File "/home/emayej/.linuxbrew/Cellar/mackup/0.8.15/libexec/lib/python2.7/site-packages/mackup/appsdb.py", line 34 by adding the encoding parameter set to utf-8:
if config.read(config_file,"utf_8")
This should work for most of the host configuration  because UTF-8 encompass Ascii. Didn't dig too much into the issue and how it is handled with python 2.

As far as I can tell, this is a problem with Lightroom (Adobe Camera Raw specifically), not mackup. Adobe Camera Raw doesn't follow symlinks.
Lightroom settings seem to be fine, just not CameraRaw.
I got around this by excluding Adobe Camera Raw in my mackup.cfg.
ini
[applications_to_ignore]
adobe-camera-raw

lachlanhunt:
I had this problem too. As a workaround, I moved ~/.mackup.cfg to ~/.mackup/custom.cfg, and added an application name.
[application]
name = custom

[configuration_files]
.gitignore_global
.git-prompt.sh
.git-completion.bash

phlind:
You can put a .mackup.cfg in the home folder of your Linux subsystem on Windows and add the following:
[storage]
engine = file_system
path = *path to your Google drive main folder*
directory = *name of the directory in the Google drive folder"
And on the main system where your original files are, you also make a .mackup.cfg, but you don't need to specify engine = file_system, but you can just say engine = google_drive and also the same path = ... like above, e.g. dotfiles.
At least I got it working like this with Dropbox on macOS and the Linux subsystem on Windows 10.. You can put a .mackup.cfg in the home folder of your Linux subsystem on Windows and add the following:

And on the main system where your original files are, you also make a .mackup.cfg, but you don't need to specify engine = file_system, but you can just say engine = google_drive and also the same path = ... like above, e.g. dotfiles.
At least I got it working like this with Dropbox on macOS and the Linux subsystem on Windows 10..
